patches.reasoning: Established prior knowledge that pupils should have before learning about the end of Roman Britain.

value: The Romans invaded Britain in AD 43.
Roman Britain was part of the Roman Empire for nearly 400 years.
Romans built roads, towns, and walls in Britain.
Roman culture influenced life in Britain, including buildings and language.
The Roman army was powerful and well-organised.

patches.reasoning: Identified key learning points for the lesson on the end of Roman Britain.

value: The Romans left Britain in AD 410 due to pressures on the Roman Empire.
Without Roman protection, Britain faced invasions from other groups.
Changes included decline in Roman-style houses and infrastructure.
Economy shifted from Roman coins to bartering and local trade.
New groups, such as the Saxons, began to settle in Britain.

patches.reasoning: Outlined common misconceptions about the end of Roman Britain and provided clarifications.

value.misconception: The Romans were forced out by the British people
value.description: It is more accurate to say the Romans left due to challenges within their own empire, including threats elsewhere.

value.misconception: Roman culture completely disappeared after they left
value.description: Many Roman influences remained, such as roads and some aspects of lifestyle, but new cultures also emerged.

value.misconception: Britain was completely isolated after the Romans left
value.description: Although the Roman departure led to changes, Britain still interacted with other cultures and groups.

value.definition: A vast empire that ruled over Britain from AD 43 to AD 410.
